title: Are private schools really that much better than public schools? - Quora

response.answer_text: As someone who went to private school from k-8 and switched to public for high school, I would say that private school and public school both have pros and cons. If you can afford private school, I would definitely recommend giving it a try just to see if your child likes it. Private School (K-8) Class size Pro: Most of my classes were only made of about 15 kids which really let the teacher get to know you as an individual and give you as much help as you needed whenever you needed it.Con: If for some reason your class had a certain kid you didn't like ( I had a few of those) you are most likely going to be stuck with them for almost every class. At my school, the kids who were at the same academic level where all placed together and had all 8 classes together every day.Rules and dress codes/uniforms Pro: Disciplines kids and teaches them authority and to respect adults (works for some kids but of course there are always some rebellious ones) Also dress codes where very strict, only allowing 12 inch inseam for shorts and tucked in shirts with belts which were enforced to “prepare” us for future jobs and uniforms at work. Only collared shirts in 5 different colors and navy and khaki pants were allowed. Sometimes I miss the uniforms because it was so easy to get dressed in the morning and I never had to worry about wearing the same outfit as someone because everyone was wearing the same thing anyways.Cons: Rules wise, there wasn't a lot of freedom. No cellphones or tablets of any sort were allowed to be used or even seen at school, which of course wasn't a problem when I was younger because no one had phones, but now with every age having them, it might be a little hard to enforce and keep kids off them. Certain teachers wouldn't even allow any candy, food, gum, or even water in their class because it was too much if a “distraction”. Talking out of turn or not tracking and tapping when you read would result in getting points off (a system my school formed for punishment, like detention) Moving onto the dress code side of things, there were many limitations on to what you could wear. No bright nail polish, dyed hair, peircings, certain hair bows and scrunchies, bracelets, hats, brightly colored shoes, etc. There were not many ways to express yourself which put a damper on some kids creativity and self confidence. And they were just plain ugly…Education Pro: Direct instruction. Classes were structured and aimed to challenge students. Rigorous learning exercises and techniques were used to make sure the material was being obtained and would be remembered. Teachers were very skilled and experienced with what they were teaching and seemed to have a passion for what was being taught (not saying public school teachers aren't). Spanish and Latin were both parts of the curriculum and allowed them to dip their toes into different cultures.Con: As you stated above, you do not want your daughter to be brought up with a certain religion. This may be an issue for certain schools you consider because mine was not advertised as a Christian school but most if not all teachers taught from a religious perspective and encouraged children to adopt their religion. Due to the small amount of children who mostly shared the same religion anyways, this teaching wasn't really oppossed or questioned. Also dealing with the small amount of children, there wasn't a large variety of classes and clubs to take. Only two languages were offered and most clubs were either aimed towards science and engineering or technology. There was also a considerable amount of homework, sometimes I would have 3 essays all due on the same day or hours of homework in each class. You had to have amazing time management to survive.Close knit community Pro: Everybody knows everybody. You know who's friends with who, everyone's parents, almost everything about them. It created a lot of friendships and a great environment to grow up in.Con: Gossip, because no one spreads it like teenage girls. You will have this wherever you send your daughter, but since noting new happened too often, new drama spread like wildfire.Year round schedule Pro: Breaks….all the time! Every nine weeks you get three off, what could be bettter. Right when you get bored from school you have a break. Creates a lot of vacation time and allows your family to travel when it's less busy.Con: The summer. My school only gave us 5 weeks off which wasn't a lot of time to do much of anything. We also never got teacher work days and never had snow days built into the calendar.Other things to consider Tuition - As you probably already know, a large sum of money is going into your kids education. Tuition just by itself is expensive, but so are most uniforms, textbooks, and school supplies.Carpool - No bus transportation is available so if possible, carpool would be a great gas and time saver.Diversity - Most of my school was full of rich white kids. I knew maybe 10 black kids from k-5 and rarely had foreign students. I didn't have a male teacher until 6th grade and didn't have a teacher of color until 7th. New kids were rare, 10 new kids if we were lucky per grade each year.Special ed - My school did not provide any learning accommodations to anyone with learning disabilities. Children who's parents hadn't taught them or exposed them to kids different to them weren't taught at school how to treat them. Most kids that were enrolled that had Tourette's or ADHD were often picked on and view as weaker and stupid.Friends - We had about 500 kids k-8 so there was only a limited about of people to make friends with. Like I said before, there weren't many new kids and not much variety in students, teachers/staff.Overall, my experience with private school was excellent k-5. The education was amazing and I really loved the environment and what I was learning. But with that being said, I really hated middle school as most kids do. The education was still excellent but there were just so many cliques and drama going around, I just couldn't deal with it. My bad experiences in middle school have definitely influenced my opinions on private school and having switched to public, I would never go back. My parents send me to private school for k-5 was the best thing they could have done for me, but I would have switched to public for middle if I could have. If you can afford it, I would definitely recommend trying it out. *I have written all of the information about my years at private school based on experiences and opinions. Mine could be the polar opposite of someone who attended the same school, but I wanted to be completely honesty so you could have more information when deciding which school to send your child to* Public School Class size Pro: Larger classes, somewhere around 25–35 kids, does make the class more interesting. Hearing from so many different people and having students with all different learning styles creates a really unique learning environment.Con: It gets loud. Having all those kids talking at once can be kind of annoying, definitely for someone who is used to a class being silent. Also the size does make it more difficult for the teacher to help everyone and make sure there are enough supplies to go around.Rules and dress codes/uniforms Pro: Freedom!!! There is flexibility in rules and dress code. Not having uniforms eliminates a significant amount of rules and opens up a vast selection of what to wear. Of course there is still the no spaghetti strap rule because shoulders are sooooo distracting and no crop tops and short shorts but you can dye your whole head if you want to, have as many piercings/accessories as you want.Con: Less rules and more freedom does have its cons though. Kids don't listen as well, some don't respect adults, others skip class. It takes a lot longer to get ready in the morning. I find myself doing a lot more shopping and spending what would have been tuition money on shoppin trips.Education Pro: Only having four classes compared to eight makes it a lot easier to manage time and focus on your work. But since block is only in high school, I can't really compare the k-8 classes schedules. The curriculum is standard, academic, honors, and AP classes are available so the intensity of work and learning is up for the student to decide. I would say having received the education from private school then switching to public, all of my classes were easy. I was placed in all honors and received two credits from middle school. Prodigies are born in both environments and really depends on if your child applies themselves. The homework load is less which is absolutely something to be happy about.Con: Common core. It might just be me coming from a more structured way of learning but I hate common core. There is a common format and plan teaching, hence the name, and the teacher can then put their own spin and style of teaching on the subject. For other students though it works just fine and they've grown up with it .Close knit community Not that this isn't at public school, just with having a close knit community with a constant cycle of new kids, it's hard to form as close of one at a larger school. Coming from a 500 kid school to 2000 kid school, the transition interesting….Traditional Schedule Pro: I love summer break so much!!!!! I never knew what I was missing out on. The teacher work days and random holidays I've never had off before is great. There are snow days built in and just a really well planned out schedule.Con: Riding the bus in the morning to be able to make it to school by 7:25 kind of sucks but it's not unbearable. Christmas break this past year was only 10 days which was kind of short but the long summer makes up for it.Other things to consider No Tuition - Saving some money never hurtsCarpool - Bus or carpool, whatever you choose, you've got optionsDiversity - White, black, yellow, purple, you've got a little but if everybody from everywhereSpecial ed - Students with learning disabilities are included in all activities and are always involved in school activitiesFriends - With tons of clubs and different classes you can take, your always meeting new people and making new friendsOverall, my freshman year at public school has been amazing. I took all honors classes and got straight As. I love the diversity and amazing group of people I get to be around. There are so many classes and clubs available to join and there's something for everybody. If there is a good rated public school in your area, I would definitely consider it. *I’ve only been at public school for a year so I don't know much about it. I've tried my best to explain the difference but there is still a gap I missed from not going to a public school for K-8* All in all, my apologies for writing a book, if there is a good public school in your area, I would send your daughter there. And if money is an issue, I would strongly recommend public school to save that money on tuition. But if there are no decent public schools in the area or if money is not an issue, private school is the way to go. Best of lucky to you and your daughter :)

My cousins Chris and Maya graduated from arguably one of the best high schools in the U.S. It’s a private institution and the cost of attendance is higher than my college tuition. At their high school 100% of students graduate. The average SAT score is pushing 1400 and every student is proficient in math. The student-teacher ratio is 6:1 and class sizes are regularly single digits. I attend a run of the mill urban public high school. It’s mostly white, economically stratified, and academically average. My school graduates slightly over three quarters of its students. The average SAT of my school is 1100 and 43% of students meet the state standards for mathematics. The student-teacher ratio is 20:1. A class of less than 23 or 24 is a rarity, and classes pushing 30 are commonplace.  My cousins received the objectively superior education. But more than that, they were surrounded with people who pushed them towards excellence. Chris and Maya went to Princeton and Dartmouth. Their best friends went to Stanford and Penn. I would bet money that every student who attended their high school chose to pursue higher education with many of them attending the top institutions the world has to offer. These kids are set up for nothing but success. And perhaps more crucially, they’re avoiding the pitfalls of the public school student body. An eye-opening experience for me was listening to Maya talk about how the biggest troublemaker at her school was put on disciplinary prohibition for being rude in Instagram comments. Whereas at my school, I can name fifteen people off the top of my head who sell drugs. A senior was taken away in handcuffs for running a revenge porn ring of underage girls. A freshman was taken to the hospital after having his head slammed into the corner of a locker for talking to someone’s girlfriend. A sophomore was sent to juvie for buying a gun and threatening to murder his pregnant girlfriend after assaulting her in public. My school isn’t some dystopian hellhole - it’s average at worst. We’re lucky that there isn’t much of a gang presence, and that we have administration that takes threats to student safety seriously. But that’s the sort of thing that shows how low the bar is. We’re lucky not to have too much gang violence in our place of education. Chris and Maya’s high school experience had them a long way from any such concerns - rubbing shoulders with the future global ruling class. Kids from rich and influential families who live in a world where police don’t show up at school to collect students for committing felonies. I’m mixing with gifted and well-connected people also. But I’m also in an environment with kids who are on a life path that will leave them dead or in prison. Put simply, my cousins probably didn’t know a single person like that, let alone have to try and sit through Spanish 1 with them. Instead, my cousins get a college prep education I can only dream of, go to Ivies, become doctors, lawyers, and world leaders, and send their kids through the same system that made them. It’s possible that they might experience some rudeness in Instagram comments. But they can guarantee that other students won’t knock their daughters up, beat them senseless, and threaten to shoot them. I’m content with my public high school experience, but it can’t hold a candle to the private one that my cousins got.

They may or may not be. This is almost like asking if hot dogs are better than hamburgers. There are some really terrible hot dogs and some wonderful hamburgers and some wonderful hot dogs and some awful hamburgers. Public schools have the advantage of funding. While some private schools enjoy enormous funding through the generosity of alumni donors, many operate on a pretty tight budget. And public school budgets may also become subject to the whims of the elected officials. Private schools may offer greater opportunity for better networking and contacts through alumni and parents. On the flip side, public schools often can do the same. It would depend upon the school. Private schools often have a board of directors that oversee and monitor what is happening at the school. The activities and work at public schools frequently are subject to approval of an elected school boards and as such the voters within an area. Public schools historically have had a diverse student population thus preparing the students to interact with a broader group of people as they become adults. School vouchers have introduced a greater diversity of students to some private schools. With the diversity of students in any school, there is the problem of what that diversity may bring. Private schools have greater control of the ideology under which they operate. If it is important to a parent that their children be educated under a certain ideology this could be an important issue. On the flip side, schools may limit their curricula based the ideology under which they operate. An excellent example of this would be human reproduction. One very conservative private school completely excluded any study of human reproduction and genetics in their high school biology classes. Private schools enjoy greater parental involvement. This writer recalls a shooting at a private school in my community. The line of cars to pick up students blocked traffic on the streets near the school despite the fact that no student was ever at risk and the students at the school are typically have a bus that takes them to and from school. Because of the student population and the atmosphere in which they are working, faculty and staff at private schools report greater job satisfaction, but may often feel constrained by the school’s ideology and, even the whim of the school’s principal. Faculty at public schools generally paid better and, in the case of at least one private school here, staff and faculty reported that they did not receive any pay for the last month that the school was open. Security at public schools is better as many have on-site school resource officers (police). The smaller size of private schools, especially when the school requires a uniform make it easier for some one who is not supposed to be on campus to become evident. There are pros and cons to each side. Much would depend upon the schools. Stanton college prep, a public school in Duval County, Florida has historically been ranked upon the best college prep schools in the US while another public school in the same area had failing grades as a school for almost five years. The students at one private school in Duval county had the opportunity to observe open heart surgery while students at another private school discovered that the school’s accreditation was not appropriate for them to even enlist in the military. So, it may be a cop out of an answer, but it depends.

I want to start off this answer by saying that I have never attended a public school. I've been at the same private elementary school from pre-kindergarten until this year, my eighth grade year of high school. Note: I was held back in Pre K,  so I am a year old for my grade. Some private elementary schools hold students for a year. My experience at private school:  The teachers: Every teacher I've ever had has been enthusiastic and happy to be teaching my class. They try to make class interesting, and try to make sure everybody understands what we are learning before they move on to a new topic. My relationship with my teachers extends beyond the classroom. I talk to them about current events and other topics, and I say hello to them when I pass them in the hall. These relationships have taught me etiquette and manors I don't believe I would have learned without them. Teachers won't hesitate to offer help. The students: At my school, every student is incredibly motivated. We all put effort into our assignments and projects, and we all believe we have potential. Any student who starts to coast will be talked to and encouraged by others to try his or her best. We have no problem asking a teacher for help, and no problem asking a question or raising a concern. As a student, I feel like I have a voice that will always be heard. The facilities: In my experience, private schools have more money from donations and tuition to expand, supply, and create better learning environments than public schools. That said, I believe that a private school's facilities are much less important than many other factors. A school might have an incredible science building, but the students still won't learn anything if they have a bad teacher.  The classes: My classes are detailed, thorough, and most importantly, interesting. We cover similar topics as public schools, but usually with different material and depth. For example, in my American History class, we  study primary sources instead of a textbook. The homework load is usually fairly high compared to other public schools. As an 8th grader, I typically have 1.5-2.5 hours of homework a night. With study halls, the work is usually pretty manageable. We are never assigned work just for the purpose of doing it, our homework always teaches us something.  The opportunities: At private school, I believe that students in general get many more opportunities to go beyond the ordinary than they do in other school settings. We can elect to play interscholastic sports, do community service projects, and join clubs, all in elementary school. I take a photography class, a cinematography class, a woodworking class, and a class on mindfulness. Every few months, we will get to listen to a speaker that the school brings in. Although it isn't universal for all private schools, some schools offer independent study programs. In Independent Studies, students get to create, research, and execute a project of their choosing. At my school, recent projects have included the construction of a drone/quadcopter, construction of surf board, construction of skis, dress making, ceramics, and more. Cons: I do sometimes have a harder time meeting people in my town because I don't attend the local schools. Although I have a perfectly fine, normal network of friends from my private school, I wish I had met more people from my community. My grade is also only about 60 kids. There are many benefits to a smaller grade, but sometimes I wish that it was bigger.  This may sound like marketing, but I promise that it is genuine. Although it has its flaws, I believe that I am incredibly lucky to attend the school that I do and would recommend applying to anybody.

This is a long answer, so if you don’t want all the details, you can just read the TL:DR at the bottom of this post. I think I’m in a relatively unique situation to answer this because of the variety of schools I’ve gone to over the years. Also, just as a preface, I’m probably coming from a more privileged standpoint considering I grew up and still go to school in New York City, which gives me much more options than other places in America. For K-3 I attended an average public elementary school in the “Gifted and Talented Program” (though I’ll talk in my summary why that really doesn’t matter). Then, in fourth grade I switched to a private school that was new in New York, but well known as a charter school on the west coast. I stayed there until the end of eighth grade where I was posed with the problem of picking a place to go for high school. There were a myriad of possibilities such as staying at my current private school, switching to a more well known private school, going to a public school, and even going to boarding school. Later in this post I’ll tell you the pros and cons of each of these choices, but I’ll tell you now, that I ended up choosing to go to a very well known and selective public high school. K-3 For K-3 I went to P.S.217, a public lower school on Roosevelt Island in NYC. The main reason I (more like my mother) chose to go here was because I was selected for the Gifted and Talented Program that’s available in some NYC public lower schools. There are some that are better than others, but I went here because it was closest to my house. Pros: Very diverse community of students where I got to experience many cultures that I hadn’t been exposed to before.Honestly more accepting than my private school (I’ll talk about this later).Good ratio of boys to girls.It’s Free. Enough said.This was a while ago, so there were probably more things that I liked, but I mostly remember the reasons why I decided to switch schools in the middle of elementary school, so sorry if I missed anything but those were mostly it. Cons: Only taught things one way, never more material. Let me elaborate, they had to stick to the material and teachers could never deviate. Always had to teach Common Core (I literally failed 3rd grade math because I did long division instead of Common Core division).Not very challenging. This can be different for others, but I had already placed out of all reading levels for the elementary school by the end of second grade.Teachers hated it if you were ahead of the class, and the school couldn’t do anything if you were.The Gifted and Talented kids took the exact same curriculum as the other kids, at the same exact pace, so there was no real difference.The arts were severely underfunded and I am more drawn to the arts, so that was a drawback.That’s everything that I can think of, but remember that I don’t know how this would work for older public schools, I’m just giving my experience. 4-8 After my public elementary school, I made the decision to go to a Pre K-12 private school in Brooklyn called Basis. Basis is a network of schools globally that share a curriculum and basic school structure. This started out on the west coast as a network of charter schools, but when they decided to move east, the first school being the NYC one I attended, they couldn’t get a charter school permit, so they just made it private. Pros: Very fast paced learning environment. In fourth grade I had about three hours of homework a night and this only increased as my time went on at the school. I personally liked this because of how different it was from my previous school.Wide range of curriculum. I took many “weird” or out of the norm classes. Here are my examples. Grade 4: Took Mandarin and an hour and 45 minute Humanities seminar (Instead of English and History). Grade 5: Took both Mandarin and Latin. I also took Classics (Instead of History). I also had two science classes: Physical Geography and plain Science. Grade 6: Here’s where things started to get really wacky. I took Latin and skipped a math level to Algebra 1. I also started taking three science classes, Chemistry, Physics, and Biology, which I all took until the end of 8th. Grade 7: Took an entire class about Logic. Grade 8: Took Microeconomics first semester, took Macro second. I also took AP World History.Really flexible curriculum. Although the actual curriculum itself is not the standard anywhere, this is something most private schools are able to do. If you’re ahead in one class they can just move you up to the next grade’s class. I did this in 6th grade. The standard for my school was to take Pre-Algebra, but I skipped it and took Algebra 1.Small Class Sizes. You get to know your teacher really well, and they are open to helping you.Although I didn’t stay for high school, you have to take 6 AP’s to graduate. Most kids take around 10. This is something most schools can’t even begin to compare to. They also have a 95% pass rate.Cons: You literally know everybody. By the end of eight grade, I literally knew everyone in the high school, and most kids from the middle school.Not a lot to do. This might have been just my private school, but because of how little people there were there were only so many clubs to join, and most were academic based, not for fun.Bad boy to girl ratio. In fourth grade there were 18 kids in the entire grade. 12 were boys, 6 were girls. This 2:1 ratio basically stayed the same the entire time I was there.Not a lot of socialization. I was honestly sick of my classmates. I’m still friends with a bunch of them, but I didn’t want to only see them. My school was extremely small. The largest my grade ever got was 60 kids. That was in sixth grade. By the time eighth grade rolled around there were only 45 kids left. Only 28 kids stayed for high school.Money. My school was on the lower side of private schools, around 35k a year, but that is still a lot.As you can see, I loved the academic aspect of my school and hated the social part. That was the main reason I decided to leave for high school, along with the money aspect. My mom said that any money saved from going to public school would go to college, and I’d rather have less college debt. Before I get into my public high school I’ll give you a quick rundown of the other two options I had for high school. Catholic/Private High Schools: I probably could have easily gotten into a decent one, and if I tried I could have gotten into a good one, but they are so expensive, and when looking at the academics they didn’t even begin to compare to my middle school, so I decided not to apply. Most of the things they offered compare to my public high school, but at the price of 50-60k a year. Boarding Schools: Generally, the consensus with these is if you go to a top 20 boarding school, you are bound to get the best education in the country. While I agree with this statement, I got deferred to my top choice boarding school, so I couldn’t go until 10th grade. I had already settled in at my HS, and honestly my HS had even more clubs than the boarding school I was considering, so I chose not to go. I also sat in on some of their classes, and I already learned the physics curriculum in middle school. Their Sophomore english class compared to my Freshman english class at my HS. For most, I would say that boarding school is the best education and the best for EC’s that they could get, but for me it wasn’t. They are also really expensive. (FYI, I was considering a top 5 boarding school) High School The high school I go to is Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, New York, and it’s literally amazing. Pros: Take all the pros of my middle school except the small class size and AP thing, and put them here. More pros: Large student body. There are 950 kids in my grade and I love it. I meet new people every day.So many EC’s and clubs. There are 250+ clubs at Stuy.Most kids take a few AP’s before they graduate, but it’s required to take at least 1.It’s Free. Again, enough said.Cons: Large class sizes. There are almost always 34 kids in my class, and teachers have a lot of students. Unless you make the effort to make sure they know you, they will probably only remember your name.You need to be independent. You won’t get a lot of help.Again, bad boy to girl ratio. My school is 60% boys and 40% girls.Conclusion/TL:DR If you have access to a top 100 public high school, I’d 100% recommend going. You’ll get amazing academic and EC opportunities and meet a very diverse group of students along the way. If you have the money though, and don’t have access to one of these public schools, a top 30-ish boarding school or one a private school is the way to go. Lower rate boarding schools aren’t worth the money, so if you can’t get into one of the top ones, I’d suggest going to a private school, higher ranked the better, and going there because of how personalized it is. If all else fails, going to a normal public high school is fine, but only if you’re willing to make the most out of it. You can still do great, but you might have to work more to get the same opportunities that you can get at the schools I mentioned before.

I went to a religious private school from Kindergarten to Senior year. And I really must say that it depends on what you want for your child. My school being religious, many parents wanted to protect their child in a small (my grad. class had 60 students), predictable, and controlled environment. They also wanted them to learn religious material. However, unlike most secular private schools, the academic scene was cut out for one type of student. This is the student that is a goody goody student, goes to youth group every night, makes A’s, and is in a ton of leadership programs. They aren’t extremely passionate about a particular subject or area of study. And they aren’t “woke” per se on like politics and social injustice. So, you can see how this would put students out of this circle at a disadvantage. For example, our school was really focused on STEM as this is apparently, the way of the future. We had tons of STEM electives, but our art classes were all taught by one teacher. Our theater was in a modular. And we had no clubs for ethnic groups, women, special interests, or any other art interest. I did start a literary magazine my junior year, not without the tug of war with administration who gave us NO funding. Also, we had no special needs programs at our school. So kids (and teachers!) with any disability could not be allowed in our school. To make matters worse we did not have an elevator which made us key targets for a civil trial. There was also very little diversity beyond Blacks. Most of my classmates were upper middle class republican whites. I could go on and on about the flaws of my school, most of which start with the hard headed, traditional administration who leave no room for new ideas or thinking. This may not be the norm for all private schools, but with a larger school, you get more opportunities, diversity, and it is more probable that a student with find their niche with so many options.

No, it’s largely a matter of selection. Students that generally go private schools are better off. Private school students might come across as smarter even though they really are not. They have more experiences, like travel, open to them. They have parents who are better off than many public school parents. This affords a whole different upbringing where the feel better about themselves and express themselves better, hence they don’t feel shy about talking in class or writing on paper. If you are not as well off as others then your upbringing suffers especially during their younger years, 3 to 8 years old. If you have a body of better off students then they will tend to realize what they need to do to do well in school. If you grow up low-income, or in poverty, chances are that your daily experiences do not develop your intellect. Music lessons, dance lessons are great for intellectual development. Horseback riding, skating, and other experiences are great for intellectual development. The poor and low income kids don’t have access to those experiences. Even playing chess is good for intellectual development. It much a matter of being efficacious. If you feel that you are smarter and can affect your environment, like the better off are and can, then you come across as smarter. Also in private school teachers can hold their students to a higher standard. If a teacher has an entire class of students with limited experiences and limited perspectives then he/she might not be able to hold his/her students to a very high standard. I urge you to see the movie THE HATE U GIVE. The main characters go to a private school since their parents feel that they will do better in that school since the local high school doesn’t have such high expectations as it’s more difficult to enforce high expectations with a study body that is difficult to work with.

Yes. But it’s not really a fair comparison. It’s like asking if a limo is really that much better than the subway. The limo is going to be a better experience for those that can take it, because not everyone can take it. It’s better by virtue of the fact that it’s not designed for the masses, but for the select few. Private schools have three key advantages: Selectivity. They can always say “no” to enrolling a disruptive student. A single disruptive student can ruin a lesson for an entire class. Private schools don’t have to deal with as many disruptions.Parental support. The parents are the paying customers, after all. Private school parents, unlike public school taxpayers, can easily take their business elsewhere if they don’t like the product they’re getting for their money. And, the very fact that they are willing to pay extra for their child’s education means that the child has above-average levels of parental support at home. The best teachers can’t do anything to motivate a student whose own parents don’t care.Teacher freedom. Private schools tend to have fewer curriculum coordinators/assistant administrators/department heads/other people telling the teachers how to do their job. Teachers are free to teach the way that they know works best for the students who are in front of them.Where I live and teach, Chicago, the selective enrollment (magnet) public high schools are some of the best schools in the country. Public and private K-8 students are allowed to apply for positions in those schools. They can be, it depends. The main thing I want to get across with my answer is how much the answer to this question depends on the local options available, and your kid and their needs. I am from a rural part of Wisconsin. I went to public schools for K-8, and a Catholic high school. Here are some thoughts based on my experiences. My public school was quite good. We had no major discipline problems, and classes were reasonably sized. My family is not Catholic (we are Lutheran). I attended my high school because, at the time, it had a very interesting math/science magnet program that enrolled about 10% of the school (the rest had a more typical Catholic school education). I had three classes a day in this program, where all my teachers had PhDs. Otherwise, I took regular classes and participated in activities like a regular student. Had I continued in public school, I would have been attending classes at the local technical college instead by my junior year if not earlier. I took Algebra II at the high school when I was in 8th grade, and I was also a year ahead in English (which continued at my actual high school; I took Senior English as a junior, and then AP as a senior). My parents did not want this for me. They wanted me to have a more normal high school experience, but with appropriate academics for my abilities, and my high school made this possible. I would have still done a lot of what I did in public school, but having to travel half an hour one-way for classes would have made being fully-integrated into the student body more difficult. Now, I am a bit of special case. What more general conclusions can be drawn? First of all, I don’t think I got the highest level of benefit out of the school, relative to some of my friends. Several of my friends from growing up also switched over to my high school, and they were average students. For one of them in particular, I think going to our school versus public school probably put him on a far better life trajectory. There were two areas in which our private school was far superior to our local public school: Troublemakers could be kicked out. In public school, we didn’t have any major troubles with violence, no gangs, minimal drug use. The main avenue for delinquency is drinking. However, many students were not terribly interested in learning or doing homework. At my high school, students who disrupted things were kicked out, including the son of school officials in one case (I knew him and liked him, but he sadly wasn’t really a fit, and later went to prison.) Being able to get rid of the troublemakers is a huge benefit to the culture of the school, which leads us to the second reason.The student culture approved of being a good student. In my class at least, and most other classes as far as I could tell, the popular students were mostly also the best students. (OK, I was only middlingly popular, but I was also barely in the top 20% by class rank because I was lazy.) Our valedictorian was widely loathed, because he was a whiny grade whore, but otherwise there was a very high correlation between your grades and popularity. Not really a causal link, but being a good student was respected, and especially, not caring about school made you an outcast and a loser. We did have a guy who didn’t do homework, etc., and he was almost more like a pet or a zoo animal than a classmate. In contrast, my sister went to the local public school, and while being a good student wasn’t going to get you bullied or make you undateable, it wasn’t considered cool.Now, some other observations. First, the public school paid better. Our teachers (even the PhD-holding ones, once you account for their other opportunities) were paid nothing. The main benefit was free tuition, so the teachers that were long-tenured tended to have multiple children in the school (hi Catholicism!) or be religion teachers. Accordingly, the teaching was at times a bit of a mixed bag. The weakest areas were math and science, which I avoided due to my magnet program. However, our school got a lot of capital funding from a local businessman who was an alum. So we were very ahead of the time in technology, at least for the area (we had a T1 line in 1995). Very few families paid full tuition, and we had a true mix of income levels, from very wealthy for the area (multi-millionaires, not billionaires), to frankly dirt poor. I gained new admiration for a classmate when I learned that he, with the approval of administration and his parents, took maybe 4–6 days off from school every year. On these days, he worked a full day at his normally part-time job in an auto body shop, and used the money to pay his tuition. So, if I had to make a list of strengths for the public school, they would be: A more consistent quality of teachingA requirement to serve all students. My high school had some limited help available for weaker students, but if you had true special education needs, you were going to have to go elsewhere.Access to vocational education. My high school had a strictly college-prep syllabus. Virtually every student went on to higher ed, although many don’t finish and for maybe 40% higher ed meant technical school.If we were comparing to the public high school in the town where my school is located, the list would also include more course offerings and activities. My local public school is roughly the same size as my private school, but the private school is located in a bigger town that has a public high school maybe three times larger. This was not the choice my parents faced, though.So, my broad generalizations would be: Private schools are often better, because they can kick the problem students out, and aren’t forced to spend resources on the high-need kids.Public schools can often offer a wider range of stuff compared to a particular private school.What decision is best for your kid depends mostly on where you live. If you live in Chicago, you wouldn’t have asked (you would already know you’re sending your kid to private school). So give us more details if you want a better answer.Finally, I should mention that I think in my case my parents really made the best choice for me. I ended up attending the University of Chicago for college, and I don’t think that would have happened had I stayed in public school. Being a Chicago alum is probably the biggest external factor that has shaped my life.

As you can see in the many answers from all over the world, experiences vary wildly with both public and private schools if you look worldwide. Even in the USA schools vary considerably. This is why: Private schools vary greatly depending on where you live, how much you can afford to spend, and what you are hoping to gain or avoid.Public schools very greatly depending on where you live and what you are hoping to gain or avoid.Measuring education is a big mess depending on what you are hoping to gain or avoid. In the USA public school effectiveness is mostly measured by test scores. Test scores might not be your idea of what makes a school good or bad but it is the leading indicator used when you read about “successful” or “ineffective” schools. It is possible to attend a school with a great deal to offer in terms of variety of courses, diversity of students, background and enthusiasm of teachers, reasonable class sizes, and if test scores are lower than other schools without those things, your school will be called less successful. Private schools (and many charters) may choose to take these tests but are not mandated to do so. So if you wanted to rank student achievement based on tests, you would not find much conclusive data. Studies that have tried to compare students across private, charter, and public schools have varied results because the measuring sticks do not have equal units of measure. In many cases researchers have found that if you compare children from a similar economic and cultural backgrounds, the private and charter school students do no better than public school students and sometimes worse. HOWEVER, I would argue that the variants between private and charter schools, in particular, are so large that these broad studies are rather useless. It would be like comparing animal speeds across continents. The cheetah speed would be averaged out with the sloth and your data would be silly. Charters and private schools offer much more variety than public schools. In terms of teacher education, elite expensive private schools often have teachers with higher credentials or degrees, however many religious and less affluent private schools have teachers without teaching credentials and without higher degrees, it all depends on the school. Many private schools have amazing resources from donations, however I have also boxed up old textbooks from my public school because a local private school has purchased them. Bottom line, know that US private and charter schools vary greatly. Private and charter schools are all over the place in terms of what they offer and how good they are at it. US public schools are more consistent in terms of staffing and resources, although this varies from state to state. Public schools will most often be ranked specifically through test score results. Ask yourself what you want your child to experience in school. Make a list, prioritize your list. Then visit your local schools, public and private, and see which are most likely to give her the experiences you want for her (and that you can afford).

I think it's interesting that you asked Adam and Charlie to answer the question...as, at least in Adam's case, he went to what is arguably the best private school in the US, so he should have some interesting thoughts on the matter. First off, it's only fair to answer this question in an aggregate/statistical sense, as every individual will differ. Overall, I would argue that a good private school is DRASTICALLY better than a good public school. Granted, there are many caveats to this. First, you didn't say "the best" private school vs. "the best" public school (in which I think there is much less discrepancy). Second, this is a very difficult thing to measure due to the confounding factors usually involved. For example, more affluent families are more likely to send their kids to private schools than more impoverished families. Thus leaving it hard to tell what was the main cause of their success later on in life, the initial affluence or the schooling. Third, you didn't define what metric you really mean when you say "better." Does this mean "a more worldly experience," "more likely to keep someone out of jail," "measured by future income," etc....so I'll just presume we mean a general notion of what's best for the student. Lastly, we should note that there is drastic variation among cities (e.g., in parts of Connecticut the best schools ARE the public ones vs. parts of Los Angeles in which the public schools are more reminiscent of jails). In general, if you look at any one of the MANY longitudinal studies comparing public vs. private across America you'll find that the students going to private schools have much higher incomes, higher levels of happiness, longer life expectancy, lower criminal rates, etc. It's quite possible all of these are due to confounding factors, but just in case they're not, I'd send my kids to private schools (if money was no object).

Charter schools are a kind of odd step-child — private dirctors, but public funding and oversight. There are also differences due to the grade level. This means that the students who would tend to have low scores are just not there in the private schools. This raises the average test scores in the private schools (and lowers the averages in the public schools where those lower scoring students end up.) The schools are not run by the government so much as regulated by government. However, the issue is whether public schools are more burdened by bureaucracy than their private school counterparts and thus less efficient. Many private schools pay their teachers less, but are able to reduce class-size and thus the teacher to student ratio. More importantly, private schools benefit from a more homogeneous mix of students, in terms of socio-economic and academic excellence. That is because most students come from more affluent and thus better educated homes, although there are exceptions to that paradigm. The concern is that most students cannot benefit from that private school environment, because tuition costs are out of reach, even if largely subsidized through government assistance in the form of tax breaks and vouchers. While vouchers, in particular, would allow more students to attend these nominally better educational experiences, that is only true for some families, by no means all - not even most. Further, the current state voucher models are not regulated by the states at all. They are not compelled to meet the same standards, meet the same overall student achievement goals and thus can say, “Our traditional students (those originating from more affluent homes) are doing fine, it’s only ‘those others’ (students from poor and lower middle-class backgrounds) that are failing.” That is precisely the challenge we are trying to satisfy. It is elusive, though. When a child comes home to an empty household, because Mom and/or Dad is out working that second (or even third!) job to make ends meet, who is encouraging and reinforcing the student’s commitment to earnest study? Who is there to help the student tackle thorny math or English homework problems, even if the parent is home, when the parents were not particularly accomplished students themselves? The truth is the private school model explodes when students come with widely diverse backgrounds - even with developmental or physical challenges with which even the best private schools are ill-equipped. This isn’t a knock on private schools, but rather the practical realities of the public school experience. What makes the move to private school supports questionable is it diverts scarce resources away from public instruction, when that instruction serves, in effect, as the “eductor of last resort.” If we are taking away from the public schools, we are further eroding the eductional experience of many students and thus taking away from a large segment of the generations that follow ours.

There were a handful of real prep schools, but when my parents balked at my going to our local high school, they weren’t willing to mortgage my college money. Which was fair, but fortunately I convince them to let try the high school, grit and all — where I got a better education, and certainly a better exposure to reality, than I would have at any of the private schools they were will to pay for. Honestly, they were pretty lame. Some were just dumping grounds for affluent kids who were discipline problems, slackers, or just not very bright. A couple were girl’s schools that were glorified finishing schools. And some were just… lame. No science labs; no AP courses. (If my parents had been willing to try the local diocesan Catholic high school, it might have been different, but they were a bit bigoted that way.) So, if you’re considering public vs. private, do some research. And talk to your kid.

Firstly, I would like to say that I live in the U.K. (funnily enough the term ‘public schools’ refers to the most prestigious of private schools such as Eton College or Charterhouse - our equivalent of public schools are known as state schools). My dad went to Magdalen College School (a private school) at my age but his elder sister and younger brother went to state schools. My mum went to a private boarding school (Ashford School) - her parents are Sri Lankan and at the time were living across the globe in Indonesia. Both my parents became anaesthetists (my mum switched to medical negligence law 15 years ago) and they expected to send me to private school. I ended up going to the local state school and I think it is one of the best decisions I made. I am a firm believer that private schools do not provide a bette education that state schools and attribute their success to the following reasons: they only select the well performing students anyway. Virtually all now have an entrance exam that you compete with the other students for your place. If you lag behind in school, it’s so difficult to catch up because you don’t understand the concepts behind different explanations.the teachers push the students to do the best that they can achieve. It’s crucial to be reassured that you can go on to do x in your life - private schools give you this confidence.the students going to private schools come from wealthier backgrounds. This means that they are less likely to come from families with divorced parents, they usually come from financially secure families so don’t have to work long hours after school is over to earn money and they have been to nurseries to get them prepared before school starts at age 4/5.*That mostly sums it up overall. No, private schools are not really that much better than public schools, when comparing students from similar backgrounds. I feel like I ought to mention two things: firstly, I live in an area where the state schools are very well performing and that secondly, lower class sizes definitely help students that are struggling (it is easy to overcome this by getting your children tutors for subjects they find difficult!!) *there is evidence of this from the fact that children in wealthier areas of the U.K. spend more hours on their work in the lockdown than those in less well off parts. Thanks for reading.

In Italy private schools have better buildings, better schedules and better canteens but, with rare exceptions, they are considered to be academically inferior to public schools. In public schools there is no mercy, every grade depends on how much you study, if you aren't good enough you have to repeat the year and if you don't study enough it's likely that you will never graduate. The private school is considered a place for those who cannot keep up in public schools or need compliant teachers to get decent grades. It's often chosen only because it offers better schedules to parents who work all day or because it has more flexible schedules for students who have special needs (such as those who are professional sportsmen or work as actors or models) and almost all private school students enter a public school in high school, in order to have a better chance of passing the mandatory national state exam to obtain a diploma. I work in a public elementary school in the suburbs of a small town and among the students there are children of doctors and engineers, the mayor's nephew, a couple of children who work as models in advertising, but also children with disadvantaged families and foreign children that come from all over the world (Morocco, Cape Verde, China, Australia, Brazil, Germany, etc.) and there are no special treatments, you can't have good grades if you don't study. Studies have shown that, despite many advantages, private school students are no better than public school students and that the best university students come from public schools, so in Italy a good student in a public school >>>>>>>> a good student in a private school.

This all depends on one’s region and what one considers “better.” In Louisiana private schools typically have less-advanced pedagogical practices than do many of the public schools. For example, public schools will almost always have RtI and SPED coordinators who work with teachers in teams to examine data, etc. Professional Development at public schools will be implemented constantly. Private schools may be considered better, however, in terms of average student achievement. This achievement most often comes in that private schools have families that can afford the tuition and are, therefore, statistically better educated. These children would have succeeded regardless of where they went. Private schools perhaps are better because they allow stakeholders to actively express faith, viewpoints, etc., that would be otherwise prohibited in public schools. Honestly, as always, I see both sides of this issue.

When I was a kid, I went to a catholic school for my first 5 years then finished in a public school after we moved. I was told that the public school was because the catholic school “was full” but I learned later that the catholic grade school I was going to was free and included busing. You only paid for high school. My observations after going to both (and knowing people from both) are that the private schools are excellent for people in the middle tier but people needing extra help or above the norm, therefore requiring extra challenges, received better resources in public schools. Fast forward to today and my 2nd child is in her senior year at a catholic school. My reasons were several fold, and my wife’s were probably different. I recognized that the schools of today were more successful in preparation than in my time. I preferred the uniforms as I watched my mother struggle with keeping up with clothing. I preferred an all girls school but was not set against a co-ed school. I do have to say, children today are much more forward and in an all girls school some girls are much more willing (and able) to explore their sexuality than they would have been able to in a co-ed or public school. Education in my mind was at least as good as the public schools. Both of my children took honors and college courses in high school. Their schools offered AP courses in way more flavors than I had heard of before although it concerned me that some colleges are not accepting credits but your PreK does not care about that. I met some of the girls my older child went to school with that received a full ride to Ivy League schools so I cannot see anything lacking in the preparation they provided. Additionally, when my oldest got to college, she started with 9 college credits, putting her ahead of everyone else. Religion seems to be an issue with you. I can honestly say that while their schools matched our religion, I know there are a portion of the students that do not subscribe to Catholicism and some who do not believe in any religion. There is a class each year but I was surprised to see there was a mix of Catholic beliefs and other religions. I personally believe that letting the child make their choices requires education in what is out there. I admit that I did not closely follow the curriculum of the religious education so there may have been slants in particular ways. When my oldest finished high school, I would have bet big money that she would have selected a non-Catholic college but that is not what happened. She is far from overly religious yet 13 years in Catholic schools did not steer her away. Finally, more than once I offered an alternative private school instead of the current one and neither child was interested. I personally did not select the school primarily because it was Catholic and another religion would have sufficed. Do not let this drive your choice unless you visit and they seem heavy handed. Approach it as a non-religious person with the admissions people and see what vibes you get. Other points of consideration. Costs are not cheap but there are needs based scholarships. Just like in college, their idea of needs differs from mine. Paying for private school for two children was a sacrifice which I can honestly say I am happy with. Clothing for school is purchased every year or two (based on care), worn only for school and we gave what was left over back for others that may have had financial challenges precluding them from having what they really needed. Yes, they needed play and dress clothes, just not as many. Yes, there still was competition whenever they could get out of their uniforms. Transportation is a challenge that has to be thought through well before making the choice. Things that they never tell you about are exam days are only for exams and when exams are done, they are expected to vacate the premises. This presented MANY challenges. Teachers’ professional development were often half days because the state counts a half day as a day of school in the required number for the year (thus shortening the days they have to pay staff). Again, transportation challenges. Uber was not cheap but it saved my butt many times! I scheduled the ride, communicated when they were getting picked up and expected a call upon discharge. Add sports and extracurricular activities in and transportation can make your head spin. With 2 children, when they were at different schools due to age differences, transportation was just that much more challenging. Personalities was something I never really thought about in private school folks. I have met plenty of kids that are not people I would want to associate with because they have an entitled personality. We have strived to avoid this in our children. Furthermore, I went to a public school in a pretty well to do suburb and the same types of people were there. This is a parental management problem in my book. Teach children how to act and who to steer clear of and their life will be easier. I do have one warning though. Do not plan to switch back and forth. I know some students who went from Catholic to public and/or the other. I was surprised to hear that private school students learned more in some areas and less in others so connecting the two can be troublesome. Make your choice and stick with it.

In the studies, on average a private school is only slightly better than a public school. That said, there are public schools which outperforms all private schools in their area. And there are areas where there’s a private schools which outperforms all public schools. My personal opinion is that the choice doesn’t matter terribly in terms of education quality. However, depending on your student, your community, and the specific schools, there may be reasons to prefer one to the other. But, there is no evidence that private schools give students a tremendous advantage in life - although certain private schools give students an advantage getting into exclusive colleges. (Note that doesn’t always/often translate into an important advantage in life.)

I attended both private and public schools, and I can tell you this: it depends. For me, public school was better in every way. The quality of public schools varies widely in the United States; where I was raised, in eastern Iowa, we had some of the best public schools in the country. When I transferred from private Catholic school to public school in Cedar Rapids, I was behind in math. The public high school I attended was superior than the local Catholic school in terms of the wide variety of classes you could take, as well as having far more advanced placement classes and extracurricular activities. Further, I was horribly bullied in the snotty Catholic school I attended, but when I switched to public school, I was able to actually make friends. I also feel strongly that a Catholic education is detrimental- I’m now an atheist, but it took a long time to get a lot of that nonsense out of my head.

There are advantages to both and downsides to both. I had my son in private preschool. It was a very short day, 3 days a week. Very small teacher/student ratio. It was of course more expensive than a public school prek. But I personally feel he learned just as much if not MORE in the 9 hrs a week as the public school kids did in the 35 hr week public school. But like I said it cost too much for full day tuition. I had him enrolled in public school for kindergarten (Texas). All of a sudden it seemed this very bright, intelligent, loving child was getting in trouble. Not really bad behavior but excitable, active, difficulty blending in socially. This continued through 4th grade. In public school the rule was “zero tolerance “ you cause the teacher's too much time or energy you get in-school or after-school suspension. In intermediate school (5th grade) it got worse to the point I took him out of public school and back to the private Christian school. His grade (5th) had only 8 students total. Any student interaction issues were handled immediately by the teacher between the involved students as a learning opportunity. After 1 ½ years we had to move to a different state due to a life event. Again back to public school and some interpersonal issues but not as bad as elementary school was. This school was much better at dealing with his issues. His first day of school (after Christmas break) the teacher handed out a short list of spelling word. My son looked at the list, handed it back to the teacher and said those were baby words and he wanted harder words to spell!!! She called and talked to me about it and had him tested by the specialist at the school who said he was (at 6th grade) a college level in reading, writing, vocabulary, spelling, grammar and editing. I could have told them all this as he had written his own “books” since he was in 2nd grade!!! I had saved them and brought them to the school to show them!!! Sadly, they never provided him with the harder work he requested. He did finally improve socially in high school when he joined JROTC and ended up in 12th grade in second in command of his chapter. All this to say public school in my personal experience has overcrowded classrooms, not enough attention to figure out how to help a child.not even realize he's beyond bright and help them not constantly punish to the point they hate school. On the otherhand public school provides opportunitirs for extracurriculars and clubs. Depending on the Private school you will most likely get lower student/teacher ratio, more individualized education and discipline (not a one size fits all). Also in our experience a much better curriculum and less discipline problems from all the kids. (Tattling, disrespecting other students and teachers, no bullying).

It depends on a wide variety of factors. Generally speaking, a school can only be as good as the administrators and parents who support it. A study once showed the factors that contributed to a public school's high test scores. An interesting find was the average of parents having advanced degrees in one neighborhood as compared to another. A cycle is hard to break and success builds success. Better educated and informed parents are more demanding of school staff and more likely to be active in reform, able to financially support programs, and often have more time to devote to volunteering at the school. It doesnt mean they are smarter or that they care more about education …it just means they are more available, especially financially. Parents can form a super strong network where they supplement school programs not paid for by the state. I taught for years at a great public school. When I first began there, most of the neighborhood kids attended private school. By the time I retired 25 years later, the school was razed and rebuilt, had state of the art technology, a beautiful school outdoor garden learning environment, a track and beautiful playground and continual high ratings. The parents were the force that turned the school around. Great teachers came and stayed. Private schools can be excellent too, but my point is that if parents are reluctant to spend big bucks on tuiton, they can work together to create a private school environment in a public school setting.

Public schools are government schools. They teach you what they want you to learn. The results are evident: 30 years ago, America was the leader in quantity and quality of high school diplomas. Today, our nation is ranked 36th in the world.High schools are not preparing students with the skills and knowledge necessary to excel after graduation. Only 1 in 4 high school students graduate college-ready in the 4 core subjects of English, Reading, Math and Science.Private Schools on the other hand:Private schools are more responsive to parents. Over 78 percent of parents who send their kids to private schools are happy with the way the teachers and staff interact with them. Of parents who send their kids to assigned public schools, 49 percent are happy.For parents who send their kids to private schools, 80 percent are happy with the academic standards. For public schools, 56 percent of parents are happy with the academic standards.In 2004, 28 percent of private school students progressed through the science pipeline to the highest level compared to 18 percent of public school students. Again, if you look at absolute numbers, more public school students reached that level, though they were less likely.

I consider myself fortunate to have attended a private high-school in Montreal. In Quebec, there is some government support for private schools and a comparatively high proportion of students attend independent schools in the province - in comparison to other provinces. (Quebec ranks very highly in comparative student performance - so government support for independent schools does not result in an educational Armageddon - quite the converse!) The fees and expenses for my school are now approximately $22,000. The bulk of this is for activities and meals. Only $4,400 is for actual tuition.So what do you get:- everything is covered for sports and activities (equipment, coaching, transportation) [In comparison, the costs and transportation duties for public school or other sports and activities fall on the parents.]- first class facilities - non-unionized teachers who manage to be professional without taking every third Friday off for 'PA' days

There is an excellent article by Spengler in Asia Times, “How America made its children crazy” It makes for interesting though depressing reading but will provide some context to this answer. While I cannot speak for Japan, China or other Asian countries, I can at best describe my experience with Indian School system. With India, the debate about school system was never about cost or social engineering but more about which schools have good facilities. Naturally, Private schools with a much more localised management were far more rapid in their decision making process and had the money to invest in resources. With public schools, the request for funds takes years to climb up the decision making ladder and concepts are already obsolete before they are put into practice. But the debate never ventured into student discipline. The constant debate about the benefits of Private or Public schools with regards to Students' academic performance and discipline seems to be an inherent "First World" problem and exclusively a Western one at that. If I am correct, USA had a mixture of Private and Public school since its inception with varying degrees of investment in both. This is country that developed weapons of war, automotive and aerospace technology and many others and not all inventors and scientists had the benefit of private schooling. So what changed? Through the 60s with socialist and "psychological studies" snake oil being hawked around, corporal punishment, respect if not reverence for the Teacher and academic achievement as a virtue was slowly abraded away. Many erudite answers have already shown students playing truant in class while it is still in progress, teachers being subject to abuse both verbal and physical and an anti-intellectualism that is inherent in left-wing classrooms. Decrease in academics, unemployability and steady erosion of Nations progress through its roots is not exclusive from such negative environment. In India, student concentration was enforced not with Ritalin or detention but with the cane and a three foot long one at that. Yes I faced the cane or rather my "rear-end" did. Yet I never turned to crime other than the occasional parking ticket nor was I throwing puppies off the roof. so all the talk of "corporal punishment" creating "career criminals" is poppycock. Combine such lack of discipline with incredibly poor ideas about technical education and one has a recipe for disaster. While working in the office in Australia, making coffee in the Kitchen, I would often come across "Bake Sales". A school child would have made cookies with his or her pocket money and would be hoping to make some more to buy an ipad. Reason for the same; The school wants each child to have an ipad so they can "learn" better. There is nothing a child is going to learn on an iPad that he or she cannot learn on a piece of paper with a pencil and an eraser. And their brain-hand coordination is much better too. Wondering how we managed in the "Pre-Ipad" days, my mind wandered to my own experience while studying in India. The school I studied in did have computers, desktops as we call them now. Back in mid 90s, such systems would have cost 25,000 in todays dollars but the school had sufficient to allow students to practice programming or coding as Westerners term those. But did we start programming straight away, certainly not. Even a simple problem like A+B=C was broken down into an "algorithm", a flow chart and finally BASIC program. As we progressed, the formulas got more and more complex, like setting matrix multiplication to a BASIC program. It was both fun and stressful especially during examination when you had to debug a program which you though was airtight. Not fun when you have only 60 minutes to debug. So what is the core lesson? Any culture where education and academic achievement comes second to social engineering is a culture that would soon run aground. We are in an era where individual skill, knowledge and hard labour in STEM sciences make all the difference in national prosperity. When a Teacher is elevated to the status of a demigod who must be respected and obeyed, the student realises early on it is their word against the teacher and the teacher wins. I feared the teacher and even more, feared the outcome if my parents came to know I was spanked at school for being truant. Such respect naturally permeates our academic performance as well. Of course, are there mediocre students, yes, Are there "about average" performers, yes. But do all of us stretch brain and sinew to learn extra. That made all the difference.

My family and I live in Taiwan; our children are Eurasian. They go to a private school for a variety of reasons. Kindergarten (K1 to K3): our local public KG has terrible facilities: it is one block with two classrooms, no outdoor play area, unless you count the public park next to it, which is not enclosed so kids could easily run onto the road or get bitten by a stray dog. Besides, spaces are limited and you must sign up while pregnant i believe. The private KG , OTH, has lovely facilities and is located inside the campus of the university where we work. The children go on walks every week, to the farm, to the little lake, etc. It is a much nicer environment. Primary school: Grades 1 and 2 in public schools have class only in the morning until 1pm. Then the kids must go home, but we, the parents work. So what happens to the children? Sending them to a cram school (private) or paying for daycare kind of beats the whole “free” part of public school. Private schools have classes or organise other activities (sports, arts, etc.) until 4pm. Classes are smaller - 30 students per class in private school v. 45 in public ones at primary level, and 45–50 students per class v. 60–70 at secondary level. Outside the capital of Taipei, foreign students and / or mixed ethnicity students are regularly discriminated against or singled out in public schools. In their private school, the teachers would not get mad when i wrote notes telling them the amount of homework was excessive and thus i had instructed my daughter(s) not to finish it all. The private school my girls attend has a good English teaching program, around 2 periods per day for a total of 8hrs per week, starting in KG, with qualified native speakers. Public schools offer only 1hour per week. My two elder daughters who are now in senior high are tri-lingual and master English as well as Mandarin. Those are the main reasons.

The teachers were not good, and even though there were only about 17–18 kids in each class, the poor behavior in each set was really noticeable. Students who went to private school vs. students who went to public schools, are more qualified or smarter is asinine. Students are only as smart as their teachers. Those teachers are only as smart as their teachers and so on.. The teacher's teacher went to same college with my family. I’m a teacher. School choice is popular in my area. We have a lot of families that transfer to my public elementary school. Not all these families live close. It doesn’t take long for families to realize that driving to our school & back home each morning and each afternoon, five days a week is exhausting. We have terrible traffic in my area too. Transfer students do not qualify for bussing. Here is a scenario. Your oldest child is sick and needs to miss school. Your youngest child is well. Now you have to have this long drive to school for just one child. Do you do it? You’d think yes, but they don’t. Many of our transfer kids have shoddy attendance. Because of unforeseen traffic issues, many have numerous tardies. Pick a school that you don’t mind driving to and from twice a day, five days a week.

Yes… and no. Education-wise, I’d say yes. The curriculum is more or less the same, but from what I’ve seen, the standard is much higher. In public schools, 50% would be a passing grade, but in a private school, the passing grade is 65%. Sports are actually okay in private schools, though the options take more time to flood in. Private schools start with two sports and then grow to have students play more sports. However, teams are larger in public schools, and they have more options to play. Behavior-wise, private schools are no better, if not worse, than public schools. Swearing, dating, getting arrested, stupid rules and all that other crap definitely happens.

Bettter funding, money from the governmant and 30k a year from parents = outstanding facilities Select entry, if you are not smart enough you dont get in = students all at the same grade level are much eaasier to teach, when I was teaching I had to deal with students from Grade 2 to 10 in the same class each one had to have an individual learning plan.
