You can’t really make a blanket statement about all public or private schools across the board because there are a lot of factors. Basically, you should look at how the school performs, especially compared to the other options in your area (or nationally if you’re considering boarding schools). There are many great public schools that will way out perform some private schools. We have some of those in my area. Likewise, for every public school that does, there are many that don’t. Essentially, it comes down to money, and, unfortunately, many of the best public schools are in the wealthiest areas because of how schools are funded. That means more resources to devote to each student. The benefit of private schools is that you are directly paying them. It is your choice (as long as they want you) which one you choose, meaning you have more control over what sort of environment the student is in, and because they charge quite a sum, that means more money to devote to each student, usually. This leads to smaller class sizes, more staff to provide individualized attention, more extracurriculars and academic programs, and other opportunities. It’s factors like the above that should contribute to your decision in choice of school, it’s just that private schools may be more likely to have those elements because that’s what people are paying for. You can’t command 10–50K a year if you don’t deliver.

My ex wife’s father was a college professor most of his adult life who taught in both public and private universities - and he taught her the value of attending a select private school: The students are all preselected to be top students. That’s it. I sent my children to both public and private schools - 3 out of 4 of the private schools were “below average” - one almost criminally bad. 3 of the 4 public schools my children attended are absolutely top schools. From my childten’s high school- in a very upper middle class Bay Area suburb- at least one person is attending each Ivy League school. A 1400 SAT score is considered slightly above average. So I am not sold on the “private school” thing

response.answer_text: I had the opportunity to go to a good private school and have gone back to visit. Comparing it to the good public school my daughter attended here is what I saw. The private school emphasized thought, it encouraged the students while holding them accountable and it had a world view where education is important for more than just a job. My daughter's good public school had adequate teachers, poor administrators, emphasized production over depth, had too many adults who did not believe in the students and were almost gleeful when the kids failed. BTW she was National Honors society and had a college merit scholarship. Even she saw the difference. Now not every private school is good and perhaps there are many public schools who prepare their students for life and not just a job, but that is not what I have seen.

It depends on what kind of private school, The Best of the Best send 100% of their graduates to 4-year colleges and get more into the ivy league and top exclusive colleges than any public school could dream of. But small white flight private schools have performance levels that aren't any better than many public schools. Because they have meager funding just like your typical Public school. The one advantage that most private schools has is it they don't have to take troubled students and they can get rid of children who are discipline problems or academic problems and public schools can't.

Note that these answers often suffer from one of the toughest problems in educational research: absences of a balanced comparison. Okay, so Sally went to private school K-9 and then transferred to a public school. While she had been happy and high achieving in her private school years, the sudden change to a moody underachiever must have been the public school, right? We don’t know what would have happened if there had been no change. And private schools quickly tell you about wonderful outcomes; no one necessarily digs any deeper. A public high school in Washington DC boasted that all of its graduates had been accepted for college. (Private schools do this too.) in the case of a public school, however, this sent reporters looking for how this result had been achieved. It turned out that the local open-admissions community colleges waived application fees. Every student was given an application and help to complete it. The applications were then sent in. And good luck getting standardized test results from a private school. They’ll show you their lovely campus, their eminently qualified faculty, their distinguished alumni, but their student don’t participate in state assessments.

When I was in high school I moved from Illinois (very good public high school) to Ohio (smaller town and average public high school) to Mississippi. In Mississippi the public high school wasn’t worth going to, but the private one was not much better as far as academics, so I did not continue in high school. I was accepted to three different colleges (Including the University of Mississippi) without a high school diploma. This was in the 1970’s when integration still wasn’t occurring in the south and most private schools were not accredited. I assume the location of the schools are crucial in answering your question. In which location are you comparing public and private schools?

Anyway, I will get back to the point and answer your question. My mother originally is from Oxfordshire and is very posh and my father is from Sheffield and isn’t so posh ( still speaks mainly Queen’s English), so living in somewhere where there is a more colloquial accent and culture was rather different. Not only that ,but because in the classroom there were all sorts of abilities and I was capable of being fairly independent, I would usually have my hand up the whole entire lesson waiting for someone to help because all the assistants and teachers helped the less capable. Now I completely understand that the less capable need more help but condering that there were only 4 children needing extra help with 30 in a class, and 3 assistants and 1 teacher in the classroom at one time, I felt that surely their time could be spread around a bit more evenly. This then led to me crying most days in the morning about going to school because I never had anyone to play with, no help in my lessons and being emotionally bullied 24/7 for 3 years. Thank God that my parents pulled me out and put me in a Private school. When I arrived, I was delighted. So many more opportunities and better qualified teachers with only 15 in a class meaning I could have more help and attention. Also, we were put in sets of ability meaning we could all bounce of each other and feel that we were going at the right pace for us. I started playing the oboe which I still play to to this day and love as well as learning how to play hockey, netball, and rounders. The education side to this school was great. However, I must mention that I am a big, shy, ginger girl with no siblings of my own so I was easy to pick on. Again, I was bullied- emotionally. With no other schools that my parents liked in the area we had no other option but to stay there for 6 years in which I was bullied by 4 girls. We went almost every week complaining to the school who did absolutely nothing. It got to the point where I wouldn’t really speak at school unless spoken to because I had been told so many times by those girls that I couldn’t talk because I had said something mean ( AKA sticking up for myself) and then they would all ingnore me or tell me to stop bothering them and go find my friends (who everyone thought were the people bullying me because I had no one else to hang out with ). So I stayed there all the way until I was 12 when we all had to leave. And now finally I am at a Public school. Playing my oboe, in the choir and in a way, in a better place. I love the people and the education. Although I don’t see eye to eye with everyone it’s ok because the people in my house are like sisters to me ( and they are also incredibly popular even though I’m not) so they stop anyone from being foul to me and we stick together. The opportunities here are immense and the school supports you which ever path you decide to take. Unfortunately, GCSEs and the pressure of being a teenager hasn’t helped. And the end result of all that bullying has led to me having bad anxiety ( especially when talking in class and to new people) which I am still fighting. This is my second year here and so far so good ( no to jinx it or anything). So in conclusion I have indeed written a bullet pointed version for those of you wanting me to get straight to the point. State school: big classesAnyone can gonot great opportunitiesonly get funds from the government so very tight budgetPrivate school: have to pay a lot of money to go there but no exams to get ingood opportunitiesgood teachersPublic school: great opportunitieshave to pass numerous exams to get inhigh fees ( can be lowered with scholarships)good teachershappy environmentbig schoolHave more money to spendHope this answers your question, Eleanor

I have attended both private and public schools at different points in my life. And while I only attended a private school for 4 years (K-3), I feel I have had enough of an experience to know for sure. When it comes to education, yes, private schools tend to be much better. Smaller class sizes allow for more personalized instruction. This, in turn, creates more success. in the students, and allows them to grow better. Some of them also offer religious classes. So, education-wise, yes, private schools are head-and-shoulders above public schools. However, in the atmosphere, private schools also have a chance to have a much more toxic environment, at least from the students. The students who are better off can feel like they have the right to do anything to the students who are less wealthy. And, if the families of the wealthier students donate enough money to the school, the administration can be too afraid of losing that funding to do anything about it. So, there are ways where private schools are better than public (such as the education), but some ways that public schools can be better than private (the enviroment/atmosphere). If you wish to get the best of both worlds, you should pick a charter school. -Allons-y!

If you are talking about middle-class or lower neighborhoods, private schools are much better than public schools. In upper middle class or upper class neighborhoods, the quality of public schools and private schools are almost indistinguishable. To put this in context, I went to a public High School in the Carmel Valley neighborhood of San Diego that was ranked in the top 100 out of all public high schools in the United States, granted that the average household income around the school was over $200,000 and a large percentage of the students parents had a graduate degree. Yes, this was a public school, but many of the programs that made it elite were due to private donations from the surrounding neighborhoods that are very wealthy.

My public school has cracked walls. The teacher student ratio is 25:1 in most classes. Despite this, it is one of the highest ranked public schools in the country. People I know from private schools have told me stories that seem almost mythical from the eyes of public school kids. A millionaire family donates a building to the school, or how individuals get private coaching on their careers, successes, and academic weaknesses. The two are so ridiculously different they are impossible to compare.  My public school is one of the “good” ones. Compared to others we have ridiculously high funding and amazing outcomes for students. Despite this it's still public school: the biggest way I can describe a difference is that at public school you can be invisible. The main goal of public school is to give everyone a form of education. Maybe it's not great, sometimes kids fall through the cracks, some people don't thrive as much as they could. But the schools don't have the resources to pay attention to each kid. They want overall stats. Private school is a business. As a business, what matters is the customer. That means it's much more individual - they want each customer to be happy, because if they aren't their entire school (read: business) is at stake. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, as it seems to make the quality of education much better. But it still brings up the argument of why a good education has to be monetized.

I will tell you something that most people will not tell you. Private schools have the right to refuse special needs children. If your kid needs help learning than they will refuse you and tell you to go to the public school. If you look at only stats than you will think private schooling is better .Of course it is better given that all their students do not need help and thus will score higher on everything. Special needs kids by their very nature will bring down stats in public schools through no fault of their own. When private schools have to take in special needs students than the stats can be equally compared. I know this because I used to be a public school Trustee.

My kids were in both public and private school, both of them. Both graduated from public school. I like private school when kids are small because I felt that they were safer at the time. There was no transferring to aftercare. But I didn't like how my son was told not to fight. I told him to defend himself, but don't get caught. He was and still is a good dude who knows how to stay out of trouble. I did not like private school because I felt that my kids were sheltered from the real world. Public school was hard for my daughter making friends and she had only 1 real friend in high school that went to private school with her. I like public school because it's more like the real world and my kids could have friends from their neighborhood. My son learned to defend himself better and he used to fight, but he never got in trouble for it. He told me afterwards. So I like both for different reasons.

I am not sure what you mean by “state schools.” Do you mean govt-funded schools (UK)? I am not sure if they are similar in fashion to US public schools, but for the purposes of this answer I will try to speak about US public schools versus private schools. It is not appropriate, in my opinion, to make a generalization that private schools are better than public schools because there are exceptional public schools that do exist. What makes private schools stand out is the amount of resources their students have because those schools are privately-funded and, thus, have substantially high budget. Due to those high budgets, they can allocate many resources to their students that an otherwise low-budget schools can’t give. Since public schools are funded by the Department of Education in each state in the US, there is only a certain limited amount of money that public schools have. Furthermore, many private schools do vet for teachers that have higher education degrees (e.g Masters/PhD), which definitely influences the learning environment for students. There are many more ways that public and private schools differ. But there are some public schools that are better than private schools. At the end of the day, I argue that if students are motivated enough then they will somehow find the resources to succeed. A school doesn’t necessarily have to define a student.

In terms of content of the subjects, no, not necessarily. But in terms of opportunities, reputation (especially if you graduate from an exclusive, private boarding school like Deerfield or Andover), it makes it big difference. Classes tend to be smaller. If you screw up/flunk, or are disruptive, you will be thrown out. Public schools have to take everyone. Those who go to private boarding schools get a head start on figuring out college and managing their lives. They learn to develop relationships with faculty. They’ll get more individual attention. But this doesn’t mean all public schools are bad. There are many excellent public schools. I think much success depends upon the parents as it does on the students. Kids who have parents who care about them, who support them, who can provide the support the kids need (be it quiet study places, tutors, extra help, visits to museums, trips, who read to them, who can guide them) will do very well in public school.

response.answer_text: This is a subject to which I have some authority. I attended a private Catholic school from kindergarten through fifth grade. From sixth grade through 12th grades I attended public school, in the same city and state. (The only reason I changed was we had moved and transportation would be an issue.) When I got to the public school I was shocked, my sixth grade year I nearly failed because they were so far behind my Catholic school! I was completely bored, things we had learned in fourth grade we were learning in sixth grade. I barely squeaked by, as they did not believe in skipping children into grades. Seventh grade wasn’t a lot better, but I things were still behind. (For comparison, my best friend in the same grade, who attended a different public school, in another district, same city and state was also behind me.) Now I see classmates of mine on Facebook from the public school who can’t put sentences together, can’t spell or use punctuation. Who were lifelong public school attendees. While many of my private school classmates are lawyers and doctors. EDIT: In my Catholic School (elementary) there were approximately 50 students in each grade, divided by 2 classes of 25 each. In my class of 50 (who I am still close and in contact with) there are two doctors, two attorneys, three paralegals, and 5 nurses. Whereas in my class of 225 from my public school, there was 1 doctor, no attorneys, 2 nurses, 1 paralegal (which is me.) I am the only one from that Catholic school, besides my sister, to attend this public school district.

A school is as good as the administrators and teachers that are involved in a public or private school.  In Philadelphia we have a public school called Masterman that has the best SAT scores in the region. It is public but the teachers have high standards and expectations.  They are always overwhelmed with the number of students who want to attend.  The private schools have the advantage of selecting students and hiring some of the best teachers.

For me yes it was. It pushed me to excel in grades and exposed me to so much more. My college prep school offered classes that were simply not available in public schools. Philosophy,psychology,film, international travel, etc. these classes and all of our class outings such as to modern dance studios,ballet, the opera, silent films and so much more. It was an incredible enriching experience for all of my class. The work was challenging and taught by Ivy League educated instructors. It opened my eyes to a world that I was mostly unaware of. For that alone, I am most thankful to my parents realizing the extra cost it was for them. I came from a working class family and it was a sacrifice for both of my parents. I am forever grateful.

“Are private schools really that much better than public schools?” It’s not true that EVERY private school is better than EVERY public school, but most are better. Exceptions are rare but they do exist. Where I grew up the Catholic elementary through junior high schools ran a year behind my public school district. My public school district was in the top few percent among public school districts. That Catholic school district in the exact same location appears to have been in the bottom few percent among Catholic school districts. Being the exception to the rule I bet my example is rare. Also I can name some other private schools near were I grew up that stayed ahead of schools in my district. I didn’t care about any of that. I sucked out all of the knowledge I could and I was not about to let some school stop me. I was at public libraries, university libraries, libraries in nearby counties, you name it. I took French, then German, then finally Russian in parallel with German and more than one AP exam. What I learned is that parental involvement on an individual level beats whatever school you go to.

Parents generally choose private schools to obtain an educational experience that fits in line with parental values. I have seen horror stories in public schools, liberal private schools and conservative private schools. Sometimes parental values are different than those in the public schools. For example, there was a Catholic Parochial School near the Lithuanian government in exile that existed in large part to preserve Lithuanian culture(I had a classmate at U of Chicago that went there). However, the biggest turnarounds I have heard about in students have been in good private schools. Private schools can and do serve needs public schools simply do not.

Public schools have some of the best educators available. Many have spent a lot of years teaching and honeing their craft. They are required to have hundreds of hours of professional development. They are observed multiple times a year and have to meet rigid criteria to stay employed. So no, private schools are probably not better then public schools. They offer an alternative that can be very expensive. Students who do the work and take responsibility for their education receive a through eduction in the public school system.

Hard to say without experiencing both. I personally experienced going to a private highschool and found that the support and resources were significantly better (in BC, Canada). I would say 'better' is not only about the level of funding, but also the focus of the school. My school was very centred on sports which was great and fun, but this limited the classes and opportunity to explore the sciences and applied sciences. Another class I would have liked to take was woodworking, a class that was not offered at my school. Basically, my answer is yes, but I would consider more about a school before judging it.

Private schools are great for individual students and TERRIBLE for the Republic Private schools can turn away or expel anyone who is vaguely challenging. Private schools don’t teach the stupid or violent or the hurt or the damaged. Private schools can ensure that students all come from the same Social group, or Religious group. Private schools can indoctrinate their students to believe the lies their parents believe. Private schools, public selective schools and public schools all give you zero points up on the board when you start university. The money you spent sending your brat to a private school is now gone and so what have you got left to help them at Uni when they need it? I am a first generation honours graduate & PhD. My father left school at 14y and my mother at 15y. My widowed mother (my father died when I was 15y) worked very hard to get me educated. She was a dressmaker. One of the things you come across time after time teaching at universities are students with private school accents whose parents spent a fortune sending them to expensive private schools and then refuse to support them at university. They come down in the world with a bump. Save the money for their university education.

We don't have a good uniform definition or description of 'better' when it comes to schools. As a society we've been working on that concept with hospitals - a 'better' hospital has 'better' outcomes - among them - fewer people die there, fewer 'adverse events' happen there, fewer outbreaks of hospital-based infectious diseases occur there - etc. As a society we haven't made the same progress with defining what is a better school or a better education - it's only safe to say that private schools are different from public schools. In that difference a family might find a school they think is better/ a school that they like better.

response.answer_text: There is no one answer to that question. Where I live in Fairfax County, VA, the public schools are some of the finest in the nation. The county is wealthy, and the tax base is solid. There is a high percentage of people here with advanced degrees, who work in high-tech (Fairfax has more internet servers than any county in the USA, and is rightfully called the internet capital of the world). The citizens here demand high quality public schools. OTOH: There are some terrible public schools in the USA. Prince George’s County Maryland has schools that are very bad. Some parents sneak their kids over the line to WashDC, and enroll their kids under false addresses, in an “underground railroad”. One hint: If you want to find where the really good public schools are, just find a real estate professional. They will steer you to where the good schools are. My wife is a real estate person. When families with school age kids come to her, looking for housing, their first question is almost always, “Where are the good public schools?”

Taking public school to mean a state school (a public school in the UK is a few paying school). My children go to private swimming lessons on a Saturday morning. During the summer, this is at a couple of local state school pools which are small, one has a basic Perspex tunnel roof, the other has just about room for three groups of 5 small children. In the winter the swim school moves to one of the two local private schools. They both have better pools than any gym or hotel I’ve every been to. My daughter’s dance school rents out one of the private school’s theatres for their end of year performance as it is a better facility than our new arts centre. A friend of mine works as a head librarian at another local private schools. They not only have a large library with a librarian, they have a head librarian. They also have stables. The facilities are just an order of magnitude better. But the there are some bloody good teachers at our local state school.

A very thought-provoking question, for sure. But before answering, you have to take into account which one is closer to your home. Both have pros and cons, but it is good to remember that our education system has so much more to offer! Charter Schools Let’s not forget about charter schools – these add so much diversity to our educational landscape. They are also free, with some of them focusing on particular subjects or interests. Are your children particularly interested in a topic studied in depth at a charter school? Then maybe this is the way to go. Homeschooling Families living far from a public or private school may want to homeschool. Parents can become teachers for their children, or hire teachers for some subjects. But online courses are now largely available for homeschoolers. These courses follow the public schools’ curriculum so children get to know a little bit from every subject, but still focusing on the ones they enjoy most. However, parents should make sure that their children get to socialize with other children in different settings. If there is a public school near your home or in the district you live, then you may want your children to attend that public school, and save money for their college education. But if money is not a problem and there is a good private school you’d like to send your kids to, then feel free to do as you please. You shouldn’t fear that your kids may not get the best education. You should better make sure that you prepare them for the real life at home, as well. Your children will make it! Don’t worry

Not necessarily. Private or parochial schools have the advantage of choosing their students. Public schools accept any students who live in the school district and in some cases outside of the school district. Otherwise, there are dedicated teachers in both public and private schools that can make a huge difference as well as competent administrators. It really depends on the ability, knowledge, and experience of the staff and the support of the parents to work together to make a successful school.

I am sure there are those who would disagree, but having served as an educator in public schools for the past 38 years, my answer is no. Public schools vow to educate every child that walks through the door, while most private schools only allow those who can afford the tuition to come inside. Students have opportunities to participate in extra curricular activities that some private schools may not offer. In addition, public schools offer young people a more realistic glimpse of the real world by exposing them to different races and cultures.

Most of the difference in performance between public and private schools is a function of selection effects. Private schools get to choose who they let in and parents have to take effort to get their kids into them. As a result, the classes tend to be filled with motivated children of motivated parents. Studies have shown that peers have a larger effect on a child's learning than parents. Thus it would follow that one of the greatest influences you can have on your child is in choosing the child's peer group. I went to an excellent suburban public school district and had a great educational experience where I got to take challenging classes with ambitious peers. At the kindergarten level it's debatable how important this all is, but it becomes more significant at the higher grades.

I have attended both public and private schooling. I have learned so much from both. But ultimately I would rather have gone to my private school for the fact that there is better teaching, less class size, better food, more time to meet with teachers, more freedom, and also a more caring community. There are some snobby people, but after awhile you get over them. My time in public school was decent, but I did not have the ability to connect with my teacher because there were so many students. Also there are some strange people you encounter that make you a little uncomfortable. So my awnser would be private is much better than public.

Which is better, grapes or pork chops?  Can't be answered, right?  Your question is the same.  I've taught in both.  Most private schools except the elite pay worse than public, but offer better discipline and smaller classes.  This attracts a certain type of teacher.  Also, all but the very worst school will have at least one very good, maybe excellent, teacher.  All but the very best school will have a bad teacher, or one who isn't right for your student.  Visit the school, sniff the atmosphere, talk to the principal/headmaster and to some teachers.  Ask where their own kids go to school.  There are no guarantees anywhere, but due diligence can help.  And never go into debt to pay for private school; you'll likely need the money for college.  (And even then if your kid learns really, really well through grade 12, college might be free.)

Nope; I was surrounded by snobbish brats (all white, but so am I) whose parents made way more money than mine (charity boy). Some were there because their parents wanted the prestige of an Episcopal day school, some because they wanted their kids not to have to go to school with a bunch of black kids and/or (overlapping) poor whites and country bumpkins. Some teachers were good (about the same ratio as in public school), but they were clearly in fear of the school admins and the parents (no union).

I’ve gone to both. I’ve been to the worst public schools and to the best private schools (it’s a long story). It’s like comparing a Toyota to a Ferrari. One is obviously better than the other. However, there are some really great public schools. It’s just that I didn’t get a chance to go to them. So, to answer the question, I liked private school better a whole lot better. More opportunities, support, an awesome community, safety, and so much more.

That is impossible to know for certain. I was a day student a private school for three years only because at the time the high school I was going to was over-crowded to the extent that two schools were being run out of the same building. For one, classes started early and ended at about 1300; at the other it started at 1330 and ran until 1800. Extra-curricular activities were not possible to run. I benefited from much at the independent school: tighter supervision of homework and study; high expectations; being imbued with a sense of purpose - all of which matched my needs at the time.

Are you kidding? I have taught in both and there is no comparison. Since when has the government been able to do anything better than what is done in the private sector. In private schools you must teach well to excellent results or you do not stay in business. Public schools just go on forever thinking that throwing money at problems solves them. In fact the federal education dept has lost millions of dollars with no explanation as to where it went. Duh!

I can not speak for all schools private or public.wp I can speak to my experience with both. I attended public schools but in an upper middle class environment in what was a predominantly Jewish neighbourhood. The kids were smart and motivated.
